sub_topic: Finding the inverse of a matrix
message_1: Find the inverse of the matrix A = \begin{bmatrix} 3 & 1 \\ 2 & 4 \end{bmatrix}.
message_2:
To find the inverse of a 2x2 matrix A = \begin{bmatrix} a & b \\ c & d \end{bmatrix}, we can use the formula:

A⁻¹ = (1/det(A)) * \begin{bmatrix} d & -b \\ -c & a \end{bmatrix},

where det(A) is the determinant of A and is calculated as det(A) = ad - bc.

For the given matrix A = \begin{bmatrix} 3 & 1 \\ 2 & 4 \end{bmatrix}, we have:

a = 3, b = 1, c = 2, and d = 4.

Now, let's calculate the determinant of A:

det(A) = ad - bc = (3 * 4) - (1 * 2) = 12 - 2 = 10.

Since the determinant is non-zero, the inverse of A exists. Now, let's find the inverse using the formula:

A⁻¹ = (1/det(A)) * \begin{bmatrix} d & -b \\ -c & a \end{bmatrix} = (1/10) * \begin{bmatrix} 4 & -1 \\ -2 & 3 \end{bmatrix}.

Now, multiply each element of the matrix by 1/10:

A⁻¹ = \begin{bmatrix} (1/10)*4 & (1/10)*(-1) \\ (1/10)*(-2) & (1/10)*3 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 0.4 & -0.1 \\ -0.2 & 0.3 \end{bmatrix}.

So, the inverse of the matrix A is:

A⁻¹ = \begin{bmatrix} 0.4 & -0.1 \\ -0.2 & 0.3 \end{bmatrix}.
